channel.title: BUbreakingSectionTwo
channel.description: This is a randomly ordered feed of the most recent entries from BUbreakingSectionTwo, skipping any feeds with errors.

item.title: Ken Griffin lays down the law on why Trump needs to back off the Fed, saying his meddling could prompt a national debt crisis
item.description: Ken Griffin warns Trump’s pressure on Jerome Powell and the Federal Reserve risks eroding U.S. institutional credibility.

item.title: Raid on Georgia E.V. Battery Plant Raises New Risks for a Shaken Industry
item.description: Foreign manufacturers were already dealing with tariffs and the end of E.V. tax credits. Now, they face greater scrutiny of their workers’ immigration...

item.title: Oil Prices Rise After Producers Announce New Increase in Output
item.description: In a show of confidence in the market, the group, led by Saudi Arabia, said it would begin unwinding a further set of agreed cuts.

item.title: Does SAP disprove the rule that Europe can’t scale tech companies?
item.description: Exclusive: SAP chief operating officer Sebastian Steinhauser on second mover advantage, preparing for AI and Europe’s barriers to innovation.

item.title: How America’s Largest Bank Helped Jeffrey Epstein, and a Show of Resistance in D.C.
item.description: Plus, why you’re wrong about your Zodiac sign.

item.title: Dow futures rise as recession fears grow while Wall Street awaits the one thing that could derail Fed rate cuts
item.description: On Thursday, the consumer price index is due, and Wall Street sees a 0.3% gain, accelerating from the 0.2% pace a month earlier.

item.title: Shooting in Jerusalem Leaves at Least 5 Dead
item.description: The Israeli police described the incident as a terrorist attack and said that the perpetrators had been killed at the scene.

item.title: Hitachi Rail Group CEO Giuseppe Marino is trying to build high-speed rail in the U.S.
item.description: Also: All the news and watercooler chat from Fortune.

item.title: A.I. Could Make the Smartphone Passé. What Comes Next?
item.description: As Apple prepares to release new iPhones this week, industry veterans shared their predictions for what will be the next big thing in personal computi...

item.title: Two Are Killed During Demonstrations Over Social Media Ban in Nepal
item.description: Protesters stormed the Parliament complex days after the government banned most social media platforms. Dozens of others were injured.

item.title: Shooting in Jerusalem Leaves at Least 5 Dead
item.description: The Israeli police described the incident as a terrorist attack and said that the perpetrators had been killed at the scene.

item.title: Millions of Londoners Face Transit Disruption as Tube Strike Takes Effect
item.description: A days-long strike on the London Underground over pay and conditions began in earnest on Monday, threatening to upend commuter journeys for most of th...

item.title: Brazilians Protest as Bolsonaro Coup Trial Nears Verdict
item.description: Tensions are heating up in Brazil as the nation enters the final week of former President Jair Bolsonaro’s trial on attempted coup charges.

item.title: Protesters March in Brazil as Bolsonaro Faces Conviction
item.description: Supporters of the former president largely outnumbered his critics on Sunday, as thousands flooded the streets in the final week of the former preside...

item.title: The most troubling feature of the job market is how thinly spread gains are, top economist says — ‘this only happens when the economy is in recession’
item.description: "Since the beginning of the year, the economy has created a paltry 600k jobs, but without the job growth in these industries, there would be zero job ...
